prompt: Facts: The petitioner filed a Writ Petition under Article 32 of the Constitution of India.; The petition challenged the constitutional validity of Section 498A of the Indian Penal Code (IPC).; Grounds for challenge included allegations that Section 498A was arbitrary, vague, discriminatory (violating Article 14), infringed upon fundamental freedoms (Article 19), and violated the right to life and personal liberty (Article 21).; The petitioner contended that the provision was being widely misused by disgruntled wives and their families to harass husbands and their relatives.; Specific arguments highlighted the alleged vagueness of the term 'cruelty' and the potential for automatic arrest of the husband and his relatives upon a complaint being filed.; The petitioner sought a declaration that Section 498A IPC is unconstitutional, or alternatively, for the provision to be read down or for guidelines to be issued to prevent its misuse. | IPC: Section 498A (Primary focus - Husband or relative of husband of a woman subjecting her to cruelty), Constitution of India: Article 14 (Equality before law), Constitution of India: Article 19 (Protection of certain rights regarding freedom of speech, etc.), Constitution of India: Article 21 (Protection of life and personal liberty), Constitution of India: Article 32 (Remedies for enforcement of rights conferred by this Part)
